La persona que aparece en la foto es la señora Hortensia Juárez esposa del señor Carlos, ya que le día de la visita el se encontraba en su trabajo.
texts.en:
The lady in the picture is Mrs. Hortensia Juárez, wife of Mr. Carlos who was at work the day of the picture. The interior of Mr. Carlos C.'s home is in need of the finishing touches. He seeks a loan since he currently can't count on the sufficient funds needed to purchase the material and pay the person in charge of the home improvements. He would like both his children to have a better house to live in. He plans on re-paying the loan with his income working as a highway official.

Translated from Spanish by Gustavo Gutierrez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finishing interior of the home

loans.name: Domingo

texts.es:
El señor Domingo R. esta agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual pudo colocar el vitropiso en toda la casa.
Esta nuevamente solicitando un préstamo para poder realizar los acabados del exterior de la vivienda ya que con el tiempo sea estado maltratando. 
Planea pagar el crédito con una parte del sueldo que obtiene de su trabajo como chofer de un camión de carga, es la fuente de ingreso de su familia. 
La persona que aparece en la foto es la señora Karla Mariela Gutiérrez esposa del señor Domingo ya que el día de la visita el se encontraba en su trabajo y quien nos atendió fue su esposa.
texts.en:
Mr. Domingo R. is grateful for your cooperation in the previous loan with which he was able to put the floor tiles in the whole house. He is asking for a loan again to be able to do the exterior finishings on the house since there has been wear and tear with time. He plans on paying for the loan with a part of his salary he receives as a driver of a cargo truck, his family's source of income. The person who appears in the photo is Mrs. Karla Mariela Gutiérrez, wife of Domingo, since the day of the visit he was at work and his wife attended to us.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finishing on home exterior

loans.name: Elisa

texts.es:
La señora Elisa C. quiere poner un salón de belleza al frente de su casa, pero no cuenta con el dinero necesario para la inversión de su negocio.
Esta solicitando su cooperación para este crédito ya que es madre soltera y tienes dos hijos pequeños, a quines les quiere dar lo mejor. 
Desea acondicionar un cuarto de su casa  y así tener más clientas ya que actual mente las atiende en la sala de la casa. 
Planea pagar el préstamo con una parte del ingreso que obtiene de su negocio ya que es la fuente de ingreso de su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Elisa C. wants to open a beauty salon in the front part of her house, but she doesn't have enough momey to invest in her business. She is asking for your cooperation for this loan, since she is a single mother and has two small children to whom she wants to give the best. She wants to outfit a room in her house and thus have more customers, since at present she attends to them in the livingroom of her house. She plans on paying for the loan with a portion of her income that she gets from her business, since it is the source of the family income.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in her business

loans.name: Genaro

texts.es:
A la vivienda del señor Genaro Ceguera le esta haciendo falta el vitropiso en la cocina de su casa, pero por el momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para realizar la mejora. 
Es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo y así poder comprar el material y pagarle a la persona se encargara de la colocación del piso. 
Don Genaro tiene dos hijos de edad escolar a quines les quiere dar lo mejor y que tengan un lugar decente don de vivir. 
Planea pagar el crédito con el ingreso que obtiene de su trabajo en un centro comercial como panadero.
texts.en:
Mr. Genaro Ceguera needs a tiled floor in his kitchen but he does not have the money to make the improvement. He is requesting the loan to buy the material and pay the contractor for the installation of the floor. Mr. Genaro Ceguera has two school age children. He wants them to have a decent place to live and he wants to give them the best in life. He plans to repay the loan with the income he earns from his job as a baker at a mall.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Francoletti-Putz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Installation of a tile floor in his kitchen

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To finish construction of a bedroom

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Maria Del Rosario G. tiene ya más de dos años dedicándole a la venta de productos de belleza por catálogos. 
Esta solicitando un préstamo para realizar varios mejoras que le esta haciendo falta a su vivienda, ya que no cuenta con el dinero necesario para realizar la mejora. 
Doña Maria Del Rosario es madre soltera y tiene un hijo bajo su responsabilidad y desea que tenga un mejor lugar donde vivir.
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias que obtiene de las ventas de su negocio, ya que también trabaja limpiando una casa particular con se ingreso pagara los gastos familiares.
texts.en:
Señora Maria Del Rosario G. has been selling beauty products from catalogs for more than two years. Since she is lacking the funds, she is requesting a loan to make various necessary improvements to her home. Doña Maria Del Rosario is a single mother and has one dependent child. She wants him to have a better place to live. She plans to repay the loan with the earnings from her sales of beauty products. She also has a job cleaning a private home and with these earnings she will pay her household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make improvements to her home

loans.name: San Juana Verónica

texts.es:
L. señora San Juana Verónica C. tiene ya más D. un año D. diciéndose a L. venta D. abarrotes.
Al negocio le esta haciendo falta mas variedad D. mercancía pero por el momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para L. inversión y no quiere descapitalizar el negocio ya que es L. fuente D. ingreso D. su familia. 
Es por eso que esta solicitando un préstamo y así poder comprar L. mercancía que le están pidiendo sus clientes que tenga a L. venta.
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias que obtiene del negocio.
texts.en:
San Juana Verónica C. has been selling groceries for over one year. She needs merchandise for her business, but at the moment she lacks the funds to purchase it. She does not want to take capital out of the business since it is the source of income for the family. For this reason, she is requesting a loan to buy the merchandise that her clients are requesting that she carry. She plans to pay the loan with the earnings from the business.

Translated from Spanish by Rachael Mossey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for the business

loans.name: Ma. Lily

texts.en: Ma. Lily P. is from the village of Pangalalan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 56 years old, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Ma. Lily operates a business buying and selling paper or junk materials. Ma. Lily has been engaged in her business for 17 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2007, Ma. Lily joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Lily has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase junk materials to sell. Ma. Lily is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Ma. Lily from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Tito

texts.es:
A la vivienda del señor Tito C. le está haciendo falta la barda al frente de la casa, ya que no tiene seguridad de para que sus dos pequeños hijo salgan a jugar. 
Solicita el préstamo para poder comprar el material, ya que el se encargara de realizar la mejora en horarios adicionales de si empleo.
Planea pagar el crédito con el sueldo que obtiene de su trabajo en una compañía como empleado. Desea que su familia tenga la seguridad cuando el no se encuentre en la casa.
La persona que aparece en la foto es la señora Angélica De La Cruz esposa del señor Tito, ya que el se encontraba en su trabajo el día de la visita y quien nos atendió fue Doña Angélica.
texts.en:
Tito C.’s house lacks a fence in front of the house. Without it, there is no security for when his two small children go outside to play. He requests the loan to purchase the material. He takes it upon himself to do the project outside of normal working hours. He plans to pay the loan with the income he obtains from his job as a company employee. He wants his family to be safe when he is not at home. The person that appears in the photo is the wife of Tito, Angélica De La Cruz, since he was at work the day of the visit, and Angélica attended to us.

Translated from Spanish by Rachael Mossey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Making the fence in front of the house

loans.name: Urpicha Ii Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Urpicha inicia su ciclo 43 con 24 socias, que realizan diferentes negocios. 
Como es el caso D. L. Señora Fabiana que es socia hace algunos años y durante este tiempo aprendió a ahorrar y le gusta las capacitaciones.
Fabiana es casada y tiene 5 hijos D. los cuales 2 estudian, Fabiana tiene un billar en un local alquilado, tiene 7 mesas, además venD. golosinas, gaseosas, actividad que realiza con L. ayuda D. su hija, Fabiana inicio su negocio con L. venta D. golosinas.
Fabiana solicita un préstamo D. 1600 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra vitrinas para exhibir sus productos y como parte D. pago D. un equipos D. sonido.
Los sueños D. Fabiana son tener un local propio para su negocio, ayudar en sus estudios a sus hijos y construir su casa.
texts.en:
The Urpicha Communal bank is starting its 43rd cycle with 24 members who carry out different activities. That is the case for Fabiana. She has been a member for several years, and during that time she learned how to save. She likes the trainings. Fabiana is married and has five children. Two of her children go to school. Fabiana has a pool hall in a rented place. She has seven tables. She also sells sweets and soft drinks with her daughter’s help. Fabiana started her business by selling sweets. Fabiana is requesting a loan for 1,600 soles. She will use the loan to buy display cases to show her products. She will use the loan as part of the payment for sound equipment. Fabiana’s dreams are to have her own place for her business, to help her children with their education, and to build a house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy display cases to show her products and part of the payment for sound equipment

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Mrs. Lucena A. is from the barangay (district) of Malaubang, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years of age and married to Ronilo A.. They were blessed with 7 children, 5 of whom are now adults, with 4 of them already married. Lucena is presently engaged in seaweed ("guso") production and culture and fishing. She also receives support from her husband, who is a fisherman. Lucena has been engaged in this business for 20 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP for every harvest from their guso production and culture.

In September 2009, Lucena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucena, as an active member under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program of PMPC, has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to add capital for her seaweed "guso" culture and production and fishing activities. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Lucena from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her general living conditions, save for future use especially for loan repayments, basic needs, guso culture and production expansion and for possible house repairs.
 
 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Amalia Kaamiño's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Amalia K., 43 years of age and married, is a resident of Malaubang, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. Amalia is the leader of a three member group accessing a loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Amalia K.’s Group". Amalia is blessed with four children, of whom three are now in their teenage years and the other one is an infant. To make a living, she decided to run a sari-sari store. She is also working as a Barangay Health Worker and she is receiving support from her husband who works as a government employee. For the past 10 years, she has been able to maintain her business and now she is earning an average net income of not less than 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month which is very helpful to secure their family income. Upon learning of the good news of Paglaum MPC being awarded the Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for COOP-LGU Partnership Awards 2006, she full-heartedly joined the cooperative in the year 2009. As an active member of the PDP-LP Program (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People), a microfinance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP as her third loan to be used for additional capital for her sari-sari store and for a new line of business which is rice retailing. The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of her family and to meet their basic needs, as well as for loan repayments to PMPC, her child’s education and for possible business expansion. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Mrs. Yeoun Sorn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Sdau Kanlaeng village, located in Kandal province, there is a group of twenty-one people who make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Yeoun S., who was born in 1971, has been chosen village bank president by the other members.  The individuals in the group  will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Yeoun S. is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family while her husband, Mr. Savuth Koem, is a construction worker who is able to earn a low salary to support his family.  The couple has a problem because their motorbike is broken.  To improve their family living conditions, Mrs. Yeoun S. is asking for a loan to buy a new motorbike to replace this old one. She is a mother of three children; one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory,  the second is attending the local public school, and the third is too small to work or study. 

All the members are shown in the photo.

He is requesting a loan to progress with the construction on his land.

texts.en:
Mr. Sal P., pictured with his wife Mrs. Channa Heang, has been married since 2000. They have two children: one son and one daughter. Both of them are still young. The family lives in a small village across Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sal is a farmer; he grows rice and vegetables on the farmland in his village. His wife has been a silk weaver since 1998, a skill she learned from her sister. Sal does not have enough capital to purchase pesticide and fertilizer to maintain his rice and vegetable farm. Hence, he is asking for a loan in the amount of $400 to help with capital.

loans.use: To purchase pesticide and fertilizer to maintain his farm

loans.name: Then

texts.en:
Mrs. Then T. (pictured above) was married in 1998 and she has two children: one son and one daughter. Both of them are in school. In the past, she used to be a garment factory worker. Now she is a silk weaver, a skill she learned from her mother. 

She asked for a Kiva loan once already. And now she is asking for her second loan of 800USD to purchase silk materials for her weaving business. She will also use a part of her loan to purchase a horse and horse-cart for her brother to launch a horse-cart driving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.name: Alecia

texts.en:
Alecia M. is from the village of Tiaman Bonifacio. She is 52 years old, married, and has 1 adult-aged children. To make a living, Alecia owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as candies, biscuits, shampoo, soap, toothpaste, and she also sells vegetables like eggplant, cabbage, cucumber, etc. in the local community. Alecia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alecia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alecia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Alecia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Alecia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.es: La solicitante se dedica a la venta de hamburguesas teniendo como ingreso semanal s/250.00, tiene 2 hijos los cuales estan estudiando. El destino del dinero es para incrementar su capital y necesidad personal
texts.en:
The applicant sells hamburgers. Her weekly income is 250 soles.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital and personal neeed

loans.name: Hai

texts.en:
Mrs. Hai C. (in the photo), is 40 years old and her husband, Mr. La Seang, is 38 years old They have been married for twenty years and have six children: one son and five daughters. The family lives in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Hai has been selling vegetables in the local market for 3 years. Her husband has been a construction worker for 20 years. She is asking for her first loan in the amount of $300 to help finance her husband's purchase of a motorbike to get to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Sath

texts.en:
Mrs. S., 61, supports her family by selling dried fish in the local market. She is married but her husband died of senility years ago. She now has two children who are married, working, and living with her at home. Also, S. buys fish in bulk at a cheap cost from her suppliers who have some fish left over. She slices the fish into small pieces, mixing it with tasty ingredients, and drying them in the sunshine. A day later, she collects those fish to sell.

S. is selling well and almost all of her customers recognize the good and delicious fish she sells. Recently, S. got a lot of orders from her customers; however, she doesn’t have enough capital to meet the requirements of the orders. That is why she has requested a Kiva loan in the amount of $500. She will be using this loan to order fish and turn it into dried fish to sell.

loans.use: To order fish and turn it into dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Sokkea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokkea U. (in the photo), 37, is a widow with one young daughter. She lives with her elderly parents and brother along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Sokkea has been selling bananas and flowers since she was young. She buys them from her fellow villagers and transports to sell in Phnom Penh market. She does not have enough capital to purchase bananas for resale. 

Hence, Sokkea is requesting her first loan of $400 to provide additional capital.

loans.use: To purchase bananas for resale.

loans.name: Jorenda

texts.en:
Jorenda C. is from the village of Sto.Nino, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sir. She is 40 years old. Jorenda is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Jorenda owns and operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling, bread, coffee, etc.in the community. Jorenda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jorenda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jorenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Jorenda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jorenda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mr. Vanna B., is 29 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sophoin Thuch (both are in the photo), is 30 years old, have been married for ten years and have two children: one son and one daughter. All of them are still young. The family is lives along National Road Number One, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Vanna has full-time employment in a company in Phnom Penh. His wife stays at home and takes care of their children. His old motorbike breaks down a lot and does not work well, which causes him to pay a lot of money to often repair it. 

Facing this, Vanna is asking for his first loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a new motorbike to replace the old one. He will then not spend a lot of money in repair costs anymore.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle for commuting.

loans.name: Borann

texts.en:
Mr. Borann Y. (pictured above), is 42 years old and his wife, Mrs. Samet Horng, is 39 years old. They live along National Road Number One, about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1991, and have three children: two sons and one daughters. 

Borann has been a driver for 10 years. He drives for a company in Phnom Penh. His wife is a farmer; she grows vegetables on her farmland in the village. Borann is applying for his first loan of $500 for his wife to purchase bamboo and nets to shelter her vegetable farm.

loans.use: To help his wife grow vegetables.

loans.name: Numeriano

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle transport services to local community members. Numeriano has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Numeriano joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Numeriano has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from GDMPC. Numeriano is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase a transport vehicle to improve the business. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Numeriano from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sophois

texts.en:
Mr. Sophois P. (pictured above), is 30 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sarem Chey, is 31 years old. They live along National Road Number One, about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, have been married for three years and have a young daughter.  

Sophois and his wife are farmers. They grow vegetables on their farmland in the village. Sophois does not have enough capital to purchase fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his vegetable farm. So, he is requesting his first loan in the amount of $1,200 to use for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy pesticide and fertilizer to maintain his vegetable farm.

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en: Mrs. Chhun K., age 42, is a local vegetable grower. As another source of family income, Chhun K.’s husband works as a vehicle trader and also works on the farm with her. He also goes to buy vehicles from people who live in rural areas and sells to other people to gain a profit. Chhun K. currently plants morning glory and cabbage, but it is difficult to irrigate her crop because her farm is located far from the water system. Therefore, she would like to ask for a loan to buy a machine that she will use to pump water for her crops. Chhun K. was busy at her farming work when the photo was taken so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy a machine that she will use to pump water for her crops.

loans.use: To use for farming and buy silk materials for his wife’s weaving business.

loans.name: Vutha

texts.en:
Mrs. Vutha C. (pictured above) was married in 1991 and she has three children:  two sons and one daughter. All of them are in school. The family lives in a small village a long National Road Number Two, about thirteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Vutha has been selling fruit (banana and jackfruit) since 1994. She buys them from her fellow villagers and transports them to sell in Takhmao market located in Phnom Penh. In addition, she also sells Cambodian cakes in her village. From 12 pm after lunch, Vutha prepares and makes the cakes by herself and sells them through the afternoon.

Vutha does not have enough capital to use for her cake selling business, so she is asking for a loan of $100 to finance her capital.

loans.use: To use as additional capital.

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Man F., 65, is a single mother blessed with a daughter who is married. Her daughter is employed and lives with her at home, while her husband died of senility years ago. Man F. uses combinations of various root trees to examine patients who lives in the village (called traditional medicine). She has learned this field from her grandparent. Man F. always walks to sell the medicine around her community, but she can’t travel to distant locations because she has no vehicle. Thus, Man F. has borrowed a loan through Kiva’s project partner, HKL, in the amount of $700 to buy a secondhand motorcycle to sell the medicine.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorcycle to sell the medicine.

loans.name: Medelyn

texts.en:
Medelyn B. is from the village of Campo II, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 30 years old and married. To make a living, Medelyn operates a business providing motorcycle services. Medelyn has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Medelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Medelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from GDMPC which was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Medelyn is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Medelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea S. and her husband have three children who are enrolled in school. They sell fresh fish in a busy market located far from their house. Chea S. and her husband wake up in the early morning and travel to where the fish is sold in bulk and hurry back to sell it at retail in the market. Chea S. has been very busy as there are many regular customers who need to purchase her fish. However, her income is not very much as her business has insufficient financial capital so she has requested a loan to increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profit.

loans.use: To increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits.

loans.name: Vang

texts.en: Vang T., 36, has built a medium store next to her house. It is the good location to earn a living. In her store, she sells  groceries that include food ingredients, can goods, plastic goods, and sweets for children. Through this she is usually able to generate $5 per day to help lessen the financial problems of her family. Vang's husband  owns a car that he uses to operate a taxi service. The couple are the parents of two school-age children.  Vang is applying for a loan to purchase a motorbike to make her family transportation easier. She will use part of the loan to order additional groceries to resell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to make her family transportation easier.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim M., 43, is a good mother who has been blessed with four children, two of whom are married and the others are single and in school. Sim M. makes a living by buying and selling used goods for a profit. She owns an old motorbike that she uses to transport used goods that she buys door-to-door in her community. She stores many hundred kgs of recycling before selling it and gaining a profit.

Her husband was a civil servant officer, but has been retired for years and now works in the business with her. Sim M. has requested a loan, which is her third loan. She will increase the financial capital of her used goods sales trade. Sim M.’s house often needs repair, so she will use some of her loan to mend it.

loans.use: To increase the financial capital of her used goods sales trade.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly S. is an old woman who currently stays at home to do housework. She is widowed and has three children who are already married and still live at home. Her two children, who work as laborers in a wine distilling company, contribute towards covering the family expenses. Ly S. has a son who needs to continue obtaining a university degree, but he doesn’t have money to pay for his school fees (he is pictured here). Therefore, Ly S. would like to ask a loan of $500 to be used to pay this fee.

loans.use: To pay school fees.

loans.name: Rang

texts.en:
Rang S., 43 years old, owns a small shop located along the street where she sells soft drinks and food. She typically makes around US$ 10 in profit each day to ensure that her family has a comfortable life. She was married but she divorced her husband years ago. She now has two school-aged kids, one of whom attends university and other one attends a high school. 

Rang S. is running her business smoothly because she has skills in public relations which she uses with her customers. She also faces a problem: her shop is too old and not attractive to the customers. To solve an obstacle, Rang S. would like to request a loan to be used to decorate her shop which will allow her to add new customers to her clientele.

loans.use: To decorate her shop so as to be more attractive to her customers

loans.name: Albina

texts.en:
Albina T. is from the village of San Isidro, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 25 years old. Albina is separated from her spouse. To make a living, Albina owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting, harvesting and selling flowers in the local community. Albina has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Albina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Albina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Albina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Albina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Jason

texts.en:
Jason J. is from the village of Poblacion 1, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 28 years old. Jason is single. To make a living, Jason owns & operates transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating motor transport services. Jason has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Jason joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jason has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC. Jason is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to repair existing engine. This will be the 18th loan taken out by Jason from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Dulamjinhuu

texts.en:
Dulamjinhuu S. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her elder three children are university students.

Dulamjinhuu operates a dairy production trading business in her town with the help of her husband. She and her family started a dairy production trading business in 1992 and have had success in growing their business. She began her business with the working capital of 150,000 MNT and since it has operated successfully for many years, she has been able to increase it up to 2,000,000 MNT. She has many plans for the future and said, “My only wish is to be able to support my children to be better people in the future”. Dulamjinhuu is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase dairy products for her retail business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Yi

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Mrs. Yi N., aged 44, who lives in the Province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she makes a living by raising pigs and crops. Since 2001, she has run this business with great success, and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living.

She is married with four children who are teenagers: one is a laborer in the garment industry and the other three attend the secondary school. Her husband assists her in the business activities. Yi N. raised her pigs two months ago, but they are not very big due to the lack of food. Because she doesn’t have money, Yi N. decided to seek help from lenders through Kiva’s project, in the amount of $1,100 to purchase many sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs.

loans.use: To purchase many sacks of pig food to fatten her pigs.

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en:
Enhtuya D. lives with her husband and two children in Chingeltey district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Enhtuya operates a consumer products trading business in her  district. She sells a variety of food products, out of a stall, at a market. Enhtuya started her food products sales business in 2007. 

Since starting her business, Enhtuya has gained much experience as a businesswoman and has built a stable operation. For the future, her dream is to own and operate her own trading center with many different types of businesses. Enhtuya is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT loan to purchase more products in order to sell at retail prices.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Moustafa

texts.en:
Moustafa is a 22-year-old single man from Lebanon. Since 2008, he has been working as a bus driver.

Moustafa is requesting, for the first time, a loan of $1,500 from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, in order to buy a car for an extra job and extra income as a taxi driver. This will be in addition to his present bus driver job which is based on transporting students and tourists.

What differs Moustafa’s work from others is his personality and special services that he provides to his clients, especially that he can bring in an extra bus in case of emergency if anything happens to his own.

Some obstacles face Moustafa during his work such as the market and the competition. He took this job from his brother who provided him with his first financial support to start this work.

Moustafa plans to be the owner of a travel agency running tourist buses.

loans.use: To buy a car to operate as a taxi

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: 30 year old N. Harriet has banked on finances from her 6 year old retail shop business to support her family of one child and her husband. It is a business she started out of savings from her small stall business where she mostly sold salt. Harriet describes herself as friendly, honest and hard working. This she says is the sole reason why her business is still in existence. She is planning on transforming her retail shop into a supermarket in the course of time. In a week, she makes profits to the tune of 50,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy in bulk items such as sodas, sugar, salt and plastics for her shop. This she says will see her earn more profits. She says this will lay a solid foundation for the future growth of her business.

loans.use: The purchase in bulk of retail items like plastics, sugar, salt,etc

loans.name: Nakirebe Womens Development Association-Mpigi Group

texts.en: For the last 7 years her Pub business in Nakirebe-Mpigi has been her springboard to financial stability. For a lady who began as a waitress, this is simply a milestone.  31 year old N. Jane is evidently a go-getter and it is for this reason that this married mother of 6 has propelled the growth of her business by leaps and bounds.  It goes without saying, that this business has been her main source of livelihood. With profits from it she has supported family and close relatives. In a week, she makes profits that total up to 50,000 shillings and with this loan, she is optimistic that she will be able to purchase more crates of beer and other liquor for her Pub. This she envisages will open for her some new financial growth horizons.

loans.use: The purchasing of more crates of beer and other drinks for her Pub

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital for her Sari-Sari store

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
This is Corazon M., 45, resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Wilfredo M., a company driver. She is the mother of seven children, two of whom are in college,  two are in high school and the three youngest in elementary school. By the grace of God, Corazon has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to keep up her youngest children’s education until they are in college. A dream for most poor Filipino parents like Corazon as she herself was a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Corazon operates a school bus service while managing a frozen food business. She managed to earn PHP3,000 net income per week from her school bus.  She sells frozen cuts of meat and native delicacies like cured hams and sausages, sweetened meats, marinated cuts and finger foods. The usual process would be to offer these products on credit, and in two weeks the customers would pay-off the product.  Corazon sells these products from her house or through word-of-mouth. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php2000 in sales every week.

To help her continue with her businesses, she is requesting a Php15, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy spare parts for maintenance of her school bus and also to buy more supplies of products like tocino (native sweetened pork), longganisa (native cured sausages) and other products of the like to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Corazon dreams to being able to give all her children a high quality education through her hard work with her businesses. She also hopes to have a successful and stable business through all her hard work.

loans.use: buy spare parts for the maintenance of school bus and also supplies of products like tocino (native sweetened pork), longganisa (native cured sausages) and other products of the like to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Zipporah

texts.en: Zipporah is 43 years old and married with six children.  She has been selling second-hand clothes for five years.  She also does farming for extra income.  She joined Faulu Kenya so that she could easily access loans.  So far, Zipporah has managed to service three loans.  She has requested a loan of 50, 000 KES to add supplies of clothes for resale and transportation of her goods.  She hopes to expand her business to improve her income and meeting the needs of her children.  She hopes to expand her business into wholesale in ten years time.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is 37 years old and married with two children.  She has been running a retail shop for ten years and has two employees.  Joyce  joined the Victory group in Faulu Kenya so that she could easily access loans; since the members of the group guarantee each other loans.  Joyce  has requested a loan of 70, 000 KES to add supplies of bananas, maize flour, detergents and other consumer products to her inventory.  She hopes to buy a piece of land and build rental houses in the future.

loans.use: To buy bananas, maize flour and detergents for resale

loans.name: Ramza

texts.en:
Ramza is a 34-year-old married woman from Lebanon who has owned a clothing boutique since 2007, selling and renting wedding dresses.

Ramza has requested a loan of $2,500 to improve and empower her business, as well as to expand her shop so that she is able to increase her income and enlarge her business. This is her fourth loan and she has always repaid her loans on time.

Ramza’s previous loans allowed her to continually improve her work. What distinguishes her shop is the good quality of her merchandise.

loans.use: To improve and empower her business

loans.name: Crusanita

texts.en: Crusanita E. is from the village of Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 37 years old and is single. Crusanita owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Crusanita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Crusanita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Cosmas

texts.en:
Cosmas is 34 years old and married with a one-year-old daughter named Purity. He has been selling car batteries for eight years and also does horticultural farming for extra income.

Cosmas belongs to the Mwangaza group of Faulu Kenya where he saves his money on a weekly basis. He previously serviced two loans from Faulu Kenya which he used to boost his business and which he successfully repaid.

Cosmas has been guaranteed another loan of 60,000 KES to purchase batteries, battery acid and battery terminals. He hopes to expand his business and employ more people.

loans.use: To buy more batteries, battery acid and battery terminals

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia D., 58, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Ferdinand D. and they are blessed with a child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own computer shop for the past few years now.

Ofelia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her computer shop.

To ensure the success of her business, Ofelia would like to apply for a PHP 14,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying equipment and other needs for the shop like accessories and repair needs.

Ofelia dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finally have her own house sitting on her own lot and also own a vehicle.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment and other needs for the shop like accessories and repair needs

loans.name: Vanchin-Erdene

texts.en:
Vanchin-Erdene B. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvs province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is the traditional Mongolian housing tent. His two children go to a local kindergarten while his wife works as a cook in their town.

Vanchin-Erdene currently operates a small bakery in his town. He started his bakery business in 2007 and makes a variety of breads and baked pastries. He is a hardworking, easygoing man who is focused on the future growth of his business. He says, “I have a plan to expand my business and to create a more efficient workplace in the future.”

Vanchin-Erdene hopes to continue to grow his business in the future and is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a small car in order to distribute his products throughout his province.

loans.use: To purchase a car to distribute his bakery products

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma S. is from the village of Binuangan, Misamis Oriental. She is 56 years old. Wilma is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Wilma owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling firewood in the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Wilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Wilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Erdenebileg

texts.en:
Erdenebileg N. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvs province, western Mongolia. The two children attend a local middle school, while his wife washes cars out of their province. Erdenebileg makes furniture in the family home. He started this business in 1998 and has since made quality furnishings for the people of his town. He wants to one day own a small carpentry shop where he can expand his customer base, sell more furniture and further improve his family’s financial situation. 

In the 12 years of owning his business,  he has not only gained experience and knowledge in making quality furniture products, but he has also gained business knowledge. Erdenebileg is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to buy a car.

loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta P. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old. Julieta is separated from her spouse and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Julieta owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling bananas in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Julieta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Julieta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Tsevelmaa

texts.en: Tsevelmaa T. is a 36-year-old  single mother who lives with her three children in Uvs province, western Mongolia. She started her business in 2005 and since then she has been able to increase her working capital up to 7,000,000 MNT. She is a hard-working and polite woman. She wants to have her own food store and build a new house for her family as well. Tsevelmaa is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase food products in order to increase her revenue.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Namutamala Womens Group-Mpigi

texts.en: 55 year old M. Latin has been operating his 10 year old retail business in Jandira-Mpigi .Out of this business which earns him 280,000 shillings a week; he has given his family an improved lease of livelihood. He has given all his children that one requisite foundation for success in life- Education. His business has been succeeding due to his cultivated sense of determination and resolve, especially in the face of seasonal business adversity. He is married and has 8 children.  He began working as a taxi conductor. He also ekes out profits from his farming business. With this loan, he wants to buy more retail stock for his shop. He wants to buy in bulk retail; items like crates of soda, sugar, salt and soap that he will at length resell.

loans.use: Purchasing more retail items like crates of soda, sugar, salt and salt in bulk, for resell

loans.name: Gereltuya

texts.en:
Gereltuya M. is 31 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Gereltuya rents and operates a small cafe in her town with the help of her husband. Her cafe serves up a variety of traditional Mongolian dishes. 

She started her cafe in 2008 with the working capital of 300,000 MNT and has since built a stable and successful operation. She is very hard-working and has built her cafe into one of the most popular dining spots in her town. 

Gereltuya is very hopeful for the future and says, " I want to own my own cafe in the future."  She hopes to soon expand her business and is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase food supplies for her cafe.

loans.use: To purchase food supplies for her cafe

loans.name: Altanhuyag

texts.en:
Altanhuyag G. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Arhangai province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His daughter attends a local elementary school and his son is in kindergarten, while his wife helps with his business. 

Altanhuyag operates a cellphone sales and repair service in his town. He started his business in 2008. He has made much progress with his business over the last year and has built a strong customer base. Altanhuyag has gained much experience operating his business and continues to improve his phone repair skills. The success of his business has raised his working capital from 1,000,000 MNT when he started to a level exceeding 2,300,000 MNT today. 

Altanhuyag hopes to expand his business in the future and dreams of one day owning his own repair shop. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase cellphones and cellphone parts in order to increase his business sales.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en:
Dolgorsuren D. is 50 years old and lives in Arhangai, western Mongolia. She lives in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Dolgorsuren operates a pharmacy business in her town. She used to work as a nurse and has found out that the pharmacy business is a familiar one to her. Her working capital now exceeds 3,500,000 MNT and with the business profits, she hopes to enlarge her operation. 

Dolgorsuren is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more supplements and a variety of drugs for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en:
Enhtuya D. is 65 years old and lives with her husband in Tuv province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger'- a traditional housing tent. Her husband works as a guard and earns 250,000 MNT in salary per month. 

Enhtuya operates a food retailing business out of a small shop. She started her business in 2008 with the working capital of 300,000 MNT and since then, it has increased 10 times. Over the years she has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. Her business is very important to her and her family. She says, "My only wish is to enlarge the business and purchase a bigger house than the one we live in now." 

Enhtuya is an open-minded, easy-going and hard-working woman. She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Wahab

texts.en:
Wahab is a 42-year-old married entrepreneur from Lebanon.  Since 1999, Wahab has been running a car mechanic business. Today, for the first time, he is requesting a loan of US$ 1500 from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. He plans to purchase spare parts for his garage. 

Wahab is proud of his experience and his strong reputation in his line of work. He notes that it has been a challenge to secure financing for his business. He decided on starting his own business because he wanted to have an independent job and not to depend on an employer. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Gantumur

texts.en:
Gantumur J. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Arhangai province of central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of Gantumur’s children attend a local middle school while his wife helps him out with his business. 

Gantumur operates a dairy product retail business in his town at the local market. He started his business in 2006 with the working capital of 100,000 MNT and since then, it has reached 600,000 MNT. Gantumur attributes his business success to his knowledge of local market demands. He is requesting a 650,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more dairy products to sell in his business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar is a 43-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has been working as a carpenter since 2005 and has many woodworking skills. He is proud of his competitive prices, honesty, experience, strong reputation and high quality products.

Omar notes that his financial situation was a challenge for him when he first started his business. He is requesting a loan of $2,000 from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua which he plans to use to purchase wood and tools for his work.

In the future, Omar plans to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and tools for his work

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en:
Narantuya T. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and son in Tuv province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. Her husband operates a taxi service business.

Narantuya operates a food retailing business out of a small shop. She started her business in 2008 with working capital of 200,000 MNT and, since then, it has reached 2,500,000 MNT.

Over the years, Narantuya has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. Her business is very important to her and her family. She says, "My only wish is to enlarge the business and purchase a bigger store than the current one."

Narantuya is an openminded, easygoing and hardworking woman. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her shop

In 2010, Restituta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her first from PMPC. Restituta plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. To make a living, Jerry owns a business venture in the transportation sector motorcycle for lease. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from the income generated in his business.
